As a female gamer who admittedly clicked on this video to reinforce my opinion that the idea of sexism in video games is stupid, I've gotta say that I completely disagree with your argument. Saying that men struggle to design games for women is fair enough, but it sounds like you're suggesting that men can't represent women at all in their games which is totally false. You don't have to be a woman to design strong female characters the same way that you don't have to be a man to design strong males. Similar to authors of books, you can design strong characters purely through good writing and an understanding of your character's psychology. I think that there are plenty of great female role-models in video games that have been designed by men and vice versa. Suggesting that guys just can't portray women is a cop-out. Also, I really can't stand the "if you don't like how video games are right now, then make one yourself and change it!" argument... I'm a consumer. Sometimes I don't like books or movies or games or art but I'm not about to become an author, a filmmaker, a game designer, or an artist just because of that. I'm not suggesting that designers should cater to my specific demands, but rather that they should just continue to pay attention to what their marketplace and userbase is saying and take their praise and criticism to continually improve their games. Strong characters make games better, whether those characters are boys or girls.

commentThread.commentText:
Not bad, but there's a misunderstanding at the beginning. I think the point that critics of the video game industry are trying to make isn't just that video games poorly utilize women; that's a mere symptom of the problem. The problem, which you touch on later, is just that the vast majority of video games are made for men, and women are often forced to buy and play these games due to a lack of alternatives. So developers should realize that games aren't just for men.

But, you more or less touched on that later in the video. You're right, people whining about this issue ought to make like Gandhi and be the change they want.

@Nick Enchev  There's this common misconception that everyone is buying into, and they say it whenever I bring up that 49% statistic, that the only reason that figure is so high is because of all the girls on their phone playing Candy Crush. There are plenty of existing studies publicly available that suggest otherwise. One 2012 study showed that 50% of around 90 women surveyed prefer consoles over pc and mobile. In 2013, an executive at Infinity Ward said that 24% of people playing Call of Duty were female. A 2015 study suggests that more women own game consoles than men. Girls ARE playing games, a large amount of them. If they aren't making an effort to become a part of the gaming industry, it's not because they only play the latest Bejeweled clone on their iPhone.

@Alexander Jones Its not really a misconception at all. There aren't MANY studies that suggest this, and you'll find that the information they go on is VERY weak at best. Some look at how many households HAVE a console, not whether the women themselves purchased them. They don't take into account what is actually being played on those consoles, and the reporting of the data is super flaky. Lastly, and I'm not sure if this has actually been studied, I imagine more PC gamers than console gamers actually try their hand at development. This is pure speculation, but makes a lot of sense for obvious reasons. I honestly think its great that the number of female gamers is rising, as every guy I know would love for his girlfriend to be into games (mine is, though she prefers to watch), but you'd honestly have to ignore a lot of data to think that there is actually a 50/50 gender split in the gaming. Just open any gaming forum, look at the number of male gaming youtube channels, and look at the types of PC/Console game purchases. Look at who really makes up the bulk of game purchasers (physical and digital). A study of of PC gamers showed that 49% were women, then you read more into the data and you find the high majority of the "light core and hard core" gamers were males, and a very small percentage of those were women. High majority of women were "casual" gamers that play different games. I don't know about the women in your life, but pretty much none of the girls I've known (i'm 32) growing up were gamers. The rise in female gaming coincides with the release of iPhone/Android devices, and the increase of indie developers on steam, xbox live arcade and PSN having more casual light game offerings.

commentThread.commentText: One of the great fallacies of people who criticize things like video games being allegedly misogynist is that they treat aspects of culture as if they were official institutions that can be changed through appeal and amendment. Video games are not an organization with a magistrate and a bureaucracy that can say, "Oh, not enough women? Let us change the bylaws and require 40% of positions be occupied by women and women's opinions in the boardroom must be applied 50% of the time." Perhaps an individual company could do that, but how would a woman feel if she knew she was hired only to fill a quota so the company could be taken off Anita Sarkeesian's blacklist? It's a field with many different companies and philosophies. Maddox isn't proposing anything condescending or unrealistic. In fact, he's proposing the only thing you can do if you want to make the video game industry more inclusive: saturate the labor pool with more women.

commentThread.commentText: Maddox, you made your career complaining about things and doing nothing else about them. Who are you to tell others it's none of their business? Something not catering to you never stopped you from complaining. "But complaining about it isn't going to change anything." The issue is that complaining IS changing things. This is the age of social media and developers are more receptive to feedback than ever before. You can't reveal a character design or release a balance patch without someone giving you a piece of their mind. So what if male developers don't perfectly relate to women? If you want to grow as a business, you should court new demographics. That's why there's market research. Catering t o nothing but the same people over and over risks desensitizing them to your products resulting in diminishing returns.

First of all, you are the one strawmanning here. I say that we need to see what proportion of video game revenue comes from females and you tell me that 50% of the worlds buying power comes from females. Since proportion of females who buy video games =/= proportion of females who buy stuff that is a strawman argument (Lord  Hidious brought this up, I just wanted to point out the hypocrisy). My google search will throw up 5 million unreliable sources  regardless of whether or not the original data is true. I'm not going to evaluate each and every source (who would?) so if you have a reliable one, share. Or would you prefer that I simply pick the top one and tell you why that one is unreliable? Third: "We also know that in sales  mobile/app games and Nintendo are doing very well, both genre's or company's that target female-friendly content." There are so many problems with this one sentence-- in addition to more strawmanning -- that I've made a numbered list. 1) Nintendo is not free of the accusations of sexism (Bayonetta 2 anyone?). 2) Sales of female friendly games are high. So are sales of non-female friendly games. This proves nothing. 3) Many mobile games don't actually have characters or have non-gendered character (i.e. Flappy Bird). They don't have sexist content because they don't hav e sex. 4) You are again assuming that the lack of sexist content has boosted these sales. It is entirely possible that the sales would be the same even if they did have sexist content. In statistics terms the null hypothesis is "A negative portrayal of women in video games has no effect on game sales." The alternative hypothesis would be "A negative portrayal of women in video games has a negative impact on game sales." You would then have to show that games wi th sexism against women have a statistically significant reduction in sales. Oh, and don't forget to control for confounding factors such as game price, genre, and which devices the games are available on. @Shay Price Well I can't speak for Tom, but I am genuinely interested in the numbers. I am studying statistics for that very reason. But the more I learn the more I realize how untrustworthy much of the mainstream media is. Over the past 6 months I've become highly skeptical of a lot of statistics being thrown around especially in regards to feminism. Their main talking points recently -- such as the wage gap or sexual assault -- have proven to be from extremely faulty studies. For me personally, one of the greatest benefits to come from the Tropes vs. Women and gamergate controversies is that they led me to discover Christina Hoff Sommers AKA the factual feminist. She is a godsend to statistically-minded people looking into gender equality because she understands what makes a reliable study, what doesn't, and when people are being misleading by comparing apples and oranges or coming to conclusions not supported by the data. On top of that she is also rational, reasonable, and doesn't view the world through a lens of "male oppression." I strongly recommend you watch a few a her videos, about video games or other topics. Even if you don't agree with her conclusions I think you'll learn a thing or two about empirical evidence and how people use statistics incorrectly to deceive. Also, while some feminists tell us to "listen and believe" which boils down to "trust us blindly," Sommers encourages fact-checking and critical thinking -- an approach that I find infinitely more agreeable.

@Shay Price "About half of the people who will play a video game today are woman. Woman make up OVER half the video game purchases but the games still make NO effort to include or represent them." You are committing a fallacy of assuming uniformity from overall statistics. Women make up half of video game users (NOT purchases) if, and only if, you include casual and social games. And the thing is, the makers of casual and social games are rarely the ones being called out as sexist, nor are they the ones that the "50% of gamers are women" statistics are being parroted towards. King Games, for example, might be well-renowned for vile business practices and legal wrangling, but they aren't widely cited as misogynists or for degrading women. On the other hand, when examining shooters, RPGs, racing games, sports games, strategy games.... basically, any of the types of games that the AAA studios would be making, the player demographics are overwhelmingly male even to this day. Misquoting statistics will not change this fact, and frankly, the AAA studios are not so immensely stupid as to radically change their entire production and marketing setup on the basis of some unsourced or misquoted statistic which doesn't match their own, or their publisher's, marketing research as to what their player demographics are. And what the actual, non-agenda-pushing research shows is about the polar opposite of the story you are telling. For example, let's look at some marketing data on the Devil May Cry series: [LINK] Note that not only did males make up 78% of the player base, but males aged 15 to 19 (28%) outnumbered the entirety of the female player base (22%). So, yes, as long as the "teenage boy" demographic by itself continues to be larger than the "women of all ages" demographic for the types of games being made by AAA studios, you can bet your stock portfolio that the AAA studios will be catering primarily towards male gamers -- because it's the obviously profitable course for them. And, again, this is not something that will get changed by complaining at the developers; if you want change, then it will have to come from either breaking into the development side of things by making the types of games you want and showing that they can be profitable, or from the player side by getting enough women into gaming-as-a-primary-hobby / "core gaming" that they legitimately make up a large portion of the player base for big game developers.

@Shay Price "The problem is those number aren't right either" How so? And what is not right about them? You are complaining that AAA studios are supposedly ignoring their allegedly large female player demographic, and yet you have not even demonstrated that it exists as a core demographic. You then dismiss hard numbers on the player demographics for a fairly typical AAA title as "not being right either", without bothering to elaborate on what is "not right" about them. Do note that, between the two of us, I'm the only one who has so far cited any statistics here to support their argument, so you aren't exactly making yourself look good. "I could say look at this AAA title World Of Warcraft where woman lead over men in terms of hours played and by age demographics in all but the younger two." Yes, you could say that. The point, however, which seems to be flying miles above your head, is can you back it up? Demographic data on WoW is very limited, but everything I've seen suggests that the player base is between 10% and 25% female, depending on the global region you are looking at. Again, that's a far cry from the unsourced female majority claim you are making. So, at this point, I have to ask: What is it you are hoping to accomplish? Are you trying to change AAA titles? Then, as I said before, misquoting statistics, tossing around bad statistics, and otherwise trying to deny reality isn't going to help; at best, it will get you ignored, at worst, it will actively hurt your goal by making the other people arguing for it look like fools by association. Change is not going to come from non-AAA gamers complaining to the AAA studios, nor from attempts to mislead AAA studios about who is actually playing their games. Simply stated: They aren't stupid enough to fall for such obvious tricks, and they are too profit-driven to take such a large risk when they are doing fine with the status quo.

commentThread.commentText: Now that's my kind of guy...
Actually "feminist" video games do exist ! They simply don't sell and don't become AAA.

Actually, complaining about it does work. You look at least 30, yet you haven't realized this simple fact. This red >flag immediately leads me to assume that you are delusional and don't know how real life works. Moreover, the excuse "if you want it to change, shut up and make video games" is a moot argument. Yes, women could sacrifice doing what they prefer to do to create games they enjoy as hobbies, but that's just unrealistic for the majority of women who don't have a passion for creating video game content. Consumers' voices matter and are regularly catered to in video games by video game developers. Feedback helps tremendously. Would you tell a male gamer who suggests there should be more interactive content or more blah blah blah to STFU and go make a video game? No, you probably wouldn't. In fact, you'd probably think that kid is just giving a helpful suggestion that perhaps video game developers would add into the game. But when a woman suggests practical armor or more representation in games, all the sudden it's forbidden territory. Yeah, I get it, boys only care about other dicks, but the gaming community doesn't consist of just dicks anymore. Women are just as much consumers as you are. Accept it. Games were originally targeted to solely males and now they're not. Women like to play video games, so we want to be represented in more meaningful ways. Moreover, if video game developers wanted to make the most money, wouldn't it be wise if they made games that attracted BOTH men and women? Yes, yes it would be.

If I had done that intentionally, you'd have a point. I didn't, which is why I asked what you meant originally so I can address that rather than my misconception. "You are to stupid to see that." Nice insult. Good to know I don't necessarily have to be polite to you in this conversation. "Where did I bring up quotas." When did I bring up quotas? Presuming you're talking about the US military (admittedly a bit of an assumption) there's been movement to fix that. I've heard that in at least one EU nation, they've already passed a law mandating women serve the as men. In some cases though, such as with regards to special forces units or officer positions, the 'prevention' has been due to the women in question failing to meet various standards, especially fitness standards, at which point you'd have to argue things like 'is biology fair' and 'is holding both men and women to the same high standards fair'. But I'm not going to argue about that, because that might get me attacked for possibly making another strawman. The point I'm trying to make right here is that for the most part, women aren't prevented from doing the vast majority of things out there that men are allowed to, and the things they aren't are being rectified. Which is why in my first post, I specifically said if "nobody is preventing them from entering an area". Obviously if they are, there's a problem. The same problem if men are prevented. Or Hispanics. Or Asians. Or Irish. Or any other arbitrary distinction. "In some jobs women don't get fair treatment in." If that's true, then that's against most laws regardin g gender equality in the US, and likely Europe as well I would imagine. The 1964 Civil Rights act was specifically written to prevent unequal treatment regardless of ra ce, gender, etc (though an argument can be made that later laws, and recommendations made by the Civil Rights Commission, pushed the balance too far in the opposite direction. I haven't actually looked into that assertion much, so I can't really argue that one way or another here) Also, this is all funny because your original post didn't say anything about women. It was about more men 'needing' to be in jobs that are 'women's jobs'. And I specifically left women out of my original reply because I wanted to focus on and dispute the general concept.
What I was basically stating was people not see jobs as gender specific.
That is something I think I can agree with. I don't necessarily think simply having a more equal distribution of people in particular jobs will help address that, but I can agree with the sentiment.

An ad hominem (Latin for "to the man" or "to the person"[1]), short for argumentum ad hominem, is a form of criticism directed at something about the person one is criticizing, rather than something (potentially, at least) independent of that person. When used inappropriately, it is a fallacy in which a claim or argument is dismissed on the basis of some irrelevant fact or supposition about the author or the person being criticized.[2] Ad hominem reasoning is not always fallacious, for example, when it relates to the credibility of statements of fact or when used in certain kinds of moral and practical reasoning.[3]

commentThread.commentText: All of you telling women to go make our own games, guess what. I'm doing it right now, been growing up playing games since I was 5 years old and 19 now and trying to fulfill my dream. It's not that easy for many girls when they grow up in a world that keeps telling them where we should belong and what we should like. I've been told contantly that games are for boys, adults would deny when I asked if I could have stuff they thought were for boys, like radio-controlled cars and a (game"boy"). I never got them, all I got was fake barbies and fake kitchen kit. I just don't get why some games like to sexualize women. Are men that desperate to see women with no brain and big boobs in games. I'm not saying all men ofcourse, but isn't it degrading to men when the game companies assume that men want that? It's so weird when real women dress really revealing we get a lot of hate, for looking like a whore.

1. "They are just women-hating psychotic giant-babies" and so forth. So far the only "feminists" gaming communities have came in contact with in connection with games are not of the actual "feminist" kind and more of the "hey let's just attack the group that just recovered from the "killergame"-debate, spread bullshit and make money of it" So far the gaming industry hasn't come in contact with "real" feminists and only with some maniacs or cons. It's like if the first clown you've ever saw killed your dog and now you have some issue with them. You can't really blame the game communities for that, the real question is: Why don't actual feminists enter that talk and spank these pseudo-intellectuals a bit that drag down the movement's name and create a better relationship? For instance: The gaming industry AND the internet communities have reacted quite positively towards emma watson's speak AND other more objective feminists as opposed to people like Sarkeesian.  2. The game boy has nothing to do with IT being only for BOYS.....thats the name of the OBJECT and it was ment to somehow personalize the console itself and not make it sound tooo techy and it had to be speakable for everyone The original work-title was: Dot Matrix Game. It's a fun little boy that you play games on. It was not just intended for gamers, but for people who normaly DIDN'T play games. Hence the "friendly" name that rolls easily out of your tongue. 3. And industries who have those are often very male-dominated, especially considering the even worse conditions during crunch-time and that its not a stable occupation and you can end up jobless for months/years without warning in addition to bad payment. Which, thanks to the online-game, f2p and casual-industry growing is something that has become desirable more and more. It does change, talking about it is a way to show that we are demanding and wanting something else. Talking about it has brought this topic into light. It's everywhere. That's no way you can deny that.

A hardcore gamer is someone who views games the way other people view sports. 

A casual sports fan is someone who tunes in every now and again to watch a random team play on their basic TV package. A hardcore sports fan is someone who spends a hundred extra bucks a month on the premium sports package, follows at least one specific team religiously, and has preferences and biases about the other teams.

To a hardcore gamer, one who fits that 3 step list just fine, games are the things they do in their spare time more than any other one thing. It's what they think about, it's what they argue about, it's what they talk about with every warm body they come across.

It's not down to the games they play, it's not down even down to how much time they spend playing them. It's down to how much of their identity is wrapped up in video games as a passtime, as an industry, and as an entertainment medium.

The reason those games are considered casual by definition is because it is a hell of a lot harder to get excited about, talk about, and argue about a game that has 10 total mechanics, no story to speak of, and relies almost exclusively on microtransactions and time delays to keep you playing. 

Try comparing that to the LA Kings and Hockey and you should see the distinction.
Censorship is not the way to go though.

@UnarmedTitan 
The problem is not about writers being incapable of writing good characters. It's more that, as others have mentioned, a lot of times the game will still perform well without good characters because other aspects carry it.

But there is also the problem of how videogame writing's usually done.

Writers are in the last position in gaming when it comes to production. Above them we have game designer, programmers, graphic designers, artists, marketers, PR, etc. Game writers usually comes into the development scene about halfway through the development cycle with most of the assets and gameplay and vision already set in stone. Game writers usually don't have any creative freedom. They are dictated by what the other sides of the development team think about the game, the assets they've put in, the tone the gameplay gives to the player, etc (which is why disparity between gameplay and story is rampant in the industry). Imagine you having to make a story on that kind of condition.

All in all, video games mostly have bad stories and characters due to the publishers or devs not giving any attention to the story and not having writers be more involved in the process of making games (for example, have them be a permanent member of your team from the start, let them make changes and give suggestions to the gameplay and graphics department, etc)

Thankfully it seems that the industry is lightening up in a huge way to games with good stories that actually makes a unified tone and massage with the rest of the game. Games like Journey, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, This War of Mine, Valiant Hearts, even Divinity Original Sin have shown that putting a good story, characters and dialogues in your game is actually worth it and can hugely increase your profit. We're starting to see a trend of indie games trying to appeal to the audience with a good story tied with it's gameplay. Hopefully this trend can spread to the AAA world.

Either all humans around the world had some telepathic link to share this common idea, or every human male was genetically inclined to this idea when they slowly began to walk upright and use tools. The only point I was trying to make by mentioning E.L. James and Tom Clancy's work is that men and women do naturally have differences in preference. Having something exist that both genders enjoy doesn't negate that both genders will still have different preferences. A writer doesn't have to write anything that will offend one gender or another to still have only a particula r gender gravitate towards it. There some some things that just don't resonate well with the average male or female. Some artists can only draw hot anime girls really well to make a career out of it, and some writers can only write sappy romance novels to make a career out of it. The majority of writers are one trick ponies.

Wow, did I just read through 73 Comments?  That aside, I really think people place too much emphasis on sexualization within video games (probably more like the entertainment industry as a whole).  Do I think it should be toned down?  Sure, maybe a bit.  Still doesn't mean that you can't enjoy the game just cause of some visuals.  Now, as for video games "being created for men only", lets look to the past a bit.  When video games first became popular, the audience for them was a male majority, female minority.  Now, as time has gone on, that gap between the majority and minority has became much closer, though most game studios still develop many games with a clear bias for a male audience.  They believe if they target the majority, then they will make more money overall.  Thus, since the majority is assumed to be male (which indeed it is, but the difference between both audiences is very little by now) they think "What do men like in a game?".  And from there we get a bunch of buff male characters, female characters who have a strong chance of being sexualized, and the actual gameplay/story.  I think that as time passes the difference between the size of the male and female audiences will eventually come to a place where it's nearly even.

replies.commentText: I would point out that, in the video games in question, (I'm assuming we're talking mass-produced shit like CoD or AC, rather than a piece of art like Transistor) everyone is a stereotype. It's not just women. They're a straight man? OK, they're brooding, if they have a personality at all. They're emotionally unavailable, have a family but are terrible fathers, and enjoy destruction in some form, usually killing. They're gay ?> Then they're a villian, but not one to be taken seriously. They are an embarrassing fop devoid of redeeming "masculine" (AKA shooty-shooty) qualities. They're a child? They're an NPC, and they're a McGuffin to be saved as the plot needs it them to be. They're devoid of emotion and usefulness, and must be carefully guarded or else hey'll die. They cannot, under any circumstances, do anything themselves. This applies particularly for girls. Look, no one likes the caricatures found in mainstream gaming. Women don't, and that is well known through series like tropes vs women in video games, but I don't think so many people know that men hate the stereotypes just as much as women, or that children, a good portion of the playerbase of the game, don't like being portrayed as useless stupid idiots. And I'd bet th e L GB< /b>>T community does not appreciate being portrayed as degenerate effeminates or as butches.  And if we're talking about games that actually try, games that tell a story, there's very little inequality to be seen. Valve is, if anything, anti-men, with women being portrayed as strong, competent leaders in all their games, and men being portrayed as gun-happy idiots or greedy, weak bastards causing the destruction of humanity (see Portal, Half-Life, TF1&2). Tomb Raider as a series is quite good a portraying women. No, seriously. I honestly don't know why it's gotten a bad wrap for having a big-breasted protagonist who sometimes wears a cutoff T-shirt. She's a strong lead who is shown being on better than equal footing with all the men in her life, and neither of those supposed knocks are in any way unrealistic, as I'm pretty sure women have big breasts and wear cut-off T-shirts. Everything done by David Cage (Beyond: Two Souls for reference ) is gender neutral, as are a lot of comedic games like Ratchet and Clank and Psychonauts. Then when you get into interactive story games (I'm distinguishing these from RPGs in that the decisions you make here matter, while in an RPG, you're following a set story), like Mass Effect, Fallout, Bioshock, and many more, the female story lines are just as fleshed out as the male ones, or the female characters are equally as important. And in the case of Fallout, even the NPCs are balanced. The ratio of male to female hookers is just about 1:1, and there's even a robot for good measure! There's your mystery and horror games, which are p urely gender neutral, though again portraying basically only men as vicious psychos, which I dislike, being a more gentle fellow myself. Sandbox games: they're sandbox games. You can be literally whoever you want. Minecraft, the Sims games, and to some extent Animal Crossing, are completely neutral. You play as you. There are no stereotypes, or, in the case of the sims, everyone gets stereotyped for laughs. No problems here. Actually, I'm throwing strategy games here, too, because you play as yourself as well. Civ never tells you you're a man or tells you yo u're a woman. You are who you are in real life. In your mobas, you have equally bad portrayals, with men being roided-up berserkers or sneaky tricksters, and women being...roided-up berserkers or sneaky tricksters. Actually, I guess it's not so bad there, as I think about it. And lastly, there's your RPGs. (I'm not covering platformers because, well, they're platformers. They are literally point a to point b puzzles. Not all that much to talk about.) RPGs are mixed. These include such titles as Fire Emblem, Transistor, Diablo, WoW, and many more. Fire Emblem and Transistor, along with others like them, are neutral. They have strong women, strong men, weak women, and weak men, a good portion of which is determined by you. The others include WoW, Diablo, Borderlands and the Elder Scrolls. These games it is somewhat fair to have a be ef with. Elder Scrolls does actually make the women more than bags of meat, where you can talk to them, get to know them, and even marry them, if you come to like them. You can have them as fighting allies in all games, though usually with less clothing. They serve a vital role in the story of all games, though there's usually less of them than men. You can make a case for the RPG genre to have issues with portrayal of women, and you'd at least be partially right, but even then, it's still not so bad as to be misogynistic, just, as Maddox pointed out, a lack of understanding. Someone clearly made the effort in Skyrim. Did it come out great? Nah, but some person, clearly a man, tried. If you want more, then get in there and try yourself! Men can only do so much guesswork as to what women want in their characters, and it's import ant for a woman to step in at that point and take charge. Men aren't keeping women out of the creative teams of games like Skyrim. The women simply aren't there! Sorry for such a long post, but I figured I should summarize everything all at once, and well, there was a lot to cover. Basically, as a tl;dr: Outside of FPS games and some unsavory RPGs, wheres the sexism? Few games make a seemingly conscious effort to piss of women, and no genre is explicitly sexist, besides FPS's which are primarily sexist towards men. In fact, most genres are indeed gender neutral. If there is a clumsiness to how female portrayal is handled, that may be due to the lack of women in the video games industry.

Games that are m ore "gender neutral" have been selling for years (not just casual games)- Like shooting games, smaller indie titles, horror-monster-types etc. There's 10 times more female awareness to gaming and the numbers are not declining, so I say- I think there's a future in gaming for games that won't be as offensively "male only". @AutismPersonified That's circular logic - women need to pay for games to show that they are interested in them...but they won't be interested in them if they're not marketed to or at least fairly represented in games....and thus will not pay for them. @Dragoon I agree we've both yet to see any sources cited on what female gamers typically play. Which means, and I'm sure you can agree the following is also true, there is no evidence to substantiate the claim it is NOT mostly "casual games". We just don't know either way at this point but neither of us in the absence of evidence can argue one over the other. 
What we do have evidence for from your earlier link to The ESA is that adult females have gaming careers just under 25% shorter than males (13 years vs. 17). We also know that the female gaming population is 82% of the male gaming population (from your 45/55 ratio). So by tailoring a game to men these companies take advantage of a significantly larger market (18%) for a significantly extended period of time (25% longer gaming career).
I completely agree there is money to be made in designing games for and marketing to women. However, it's a business with the objective to make the most money possible (most businesses anyway). Why would they take limited resources (employees, and money) from teams designing games for a larger target market and assign them to less profitable ventures. By taking resources away from the products being designed for the larger target market you also lessen the quality of the end product and risk alienating/losing support of this larger market. 
The fact is if a business invests, arbitrary and likely unrealistic amount I don't know, $1 million and designs a game for women or takes that same $1 million and designs a game for men. Who am I making more profit off of? I'm going with men every time, no homo (not that there's anything wrong with that). The market is already there why invest resources in trying to develop a lesser market.
I'm not trying to argue I'm just spitballing ideas from the other perspective. I completely agree if someone stuck there head out to develop the market, there could be a huge reward and other companies would jump on board. The problem is no one wants to invest in the work and take that initial loss vs. solely reap the reward.

@SimplyMayaBeauty  That's an inaccurate analogy. Magazines are meant to be read by "readers," readers by definition are both male and female, not just women. So magazines should cater to both or they are losing out essentially 50% of the market. That being said - I agree with you, it's absurd to ignore female gamers. And it's also preposterous to say that men should just design for men and that women should just design for women. However, socio-culturally speaking, each gender (note the word gender, no t sex) tends to relate to their respective genders better. I do agree, giant breasts and damsels in distress don't always work - they don't with me. At the same time, uber-machismo men don't work with me either.  The industry has a lot of potential for growth and improvement, but Maddox's comments - while unpleasant to hear - still stands. Of course, getting into the industry and creating interest in the industry, that's another issue on structural and social culture that has to be addressed.

The point I made later on explains the difference between "gaming" and a magazine. When you market a specific magazine, you market it specifically with gender in mind- the magazine revolves around gender interests- If you open "Cosmo", you'll see how the articles revolve around women's issues and interests and the titles for these articles will be the draw to read the magazine. But the main "core" of a game is to be entertaining in general, and even if the main consumers are male, it's not marketed as a "male game" and "female game", like most popular magazines tend to do- It's a shooting game, so you'll play it because it looks like a lot of fun. Even if the game is designed and marketed with male consumers in mind, it's not the essence of the marketed product. But if you want to use this analogy- There're also a lot of popular magazines that are prett y gender neutral purely because their topics are neutral- like magazines about movies and literature.

The reason magazines are marketed with gender-specific audiences in mind is because there's a strong demand on both genders and a strong representation of both genders in the publishing world. I work in mass media, fyi. And that's the problem with gaming - there's low representation. I'm well aware that female gamers make a significant percentage (though I remain skeptical about the 45/55 argument), and it's exactly because female gamers are getting vocal that you're seeing changes being made. But the problem remains with your original analogy - games are for gamers, magazines are for readers. You subsequently drill down - women's health magazines are for women. To which I would respond, shooters are for FPS gamers - which are predominantly male. Casual games are for casual gamers - which are fairly gender neutral. So rounding back to my original point - your distinction* is problematic because it is simply far too vague. And you cannot argue that if the game is designed and marketed with male consumers in mind, it's not the essence. It IS the essence. The main core of a game, or even a magazine, is to be entertaining for its target audience, not to be simply "entertaining." A magazine marketed at women and designed with women in mind - Cosmo in this case - becomes its very essence. It's not about health or beauty or issues of both genders, it's about women-specific topics. Rightfully so. Because that is its audience.  Edit: Made some small edits because I was too hungry to brain properly.
